visuals.title: The Periodic Impulse Train
visuals.description: An infinite train of equally-spaced Dirac impulses, each separated by T₀ seconds. Despite having zero width, each impulse has unit area.

visuals.title: Impulse Train Spectrum: All Harmonics Equal
visuals.description: Every coefficient X_k = 1/T₀ — flat magnitude across all harmonics. The impulse train contains all frequencies equally.

visuals.title: Deriving the Impulse Train FS
visuals.description: The sifting property of δ(t) extracts the value at t = 0. Since e^{−jkω₀·0} = 1, every coefficient evaluates to 1/T₀ regardless of k.

visuals.title: The Triangular Pulse Train
visuals.description: A periodic triangular wave that ramps linearly up and down. Continuous everywhere but has corners at peaks and valleys. Derived by integrating a square wave.

visuals.title: Triangular Pulse Spectrum: sinc² Envelope
visuals.description: The coefficients follow a sinc² envelope, decaying as 1/k². The faster decay reflects the triangular wave's continuity.

visuals.title: Decay Comparison: Square (1/k) vs Triangular (1/k²)
visuals.description: The square wave coefficients decay as 1/k (slow). The triangular wave decays as 1/k² (fast). Extra smoothness buys faster convergence.

visuals.title: Integration Chain: Impulse → Square → Triangle
visuals.description: Each integration smooths the signal and adds 1/k to the decay rate. Impulse (flat) → integrate → square (1/k) → integrate → triangle (1/k²).

visuals.title: Interactive: Reconstruct the Triangular Wave from Harmonics
visuals.description: Build the triangular wave by adding harmonics. Notice how much fewer terms are needed compared to the square wave.

visuals.title: Convergence: Triangle (5 harmonics) vs Square (5 harmonics)
visuals.description: With 5 harmonics, the triangular reconstruction is nearly perfect while the square wave still has visible Gibbs overshoot.

visuals.title: Interactive: Compare Coefficient Decay Rates
visuals.description: Switch between impulse, square, and triangular waveforms. Watch how the spectrum changes from flat to 1/k to 1/k².
